title: ISM-New York Index Falls to 40-Month Low in September
text:
By Dave Sebastian

A closely watched measure of business conditions in the New York metro area plunged to a 40-month low in September from August's four-month high, according to a monthly report released Wednesday.

The New York chapter of the Institute for Supply Management said that current business conditions on the index fell to 42.8 in September from 50.3 in August. The index's reading was 43.5 in July and 50 in June.

Readings above 50 indicate a faster pace of activity while those below 50 represent a slower rate of activity.

Employment, which is seasonally adjusted, fell to a 19-month low of 52.5 in September from August's nine-month high of 69.

Current revenue, which ISM-New York said had never been in the 30s, declined to 38.1 in September from the breakeven point of 50 in August.

Expected revenue fell 37.1 points to 45.2 in September from 82.3 in August.

The quantity of purchases slid to a three-month low of 38.6 in September from 50 in August.

The prices paid by manufacturers increased to a four-month high of 71.4 in September from 66.1 in August.

The six-month outlook declined to 45.2 in September from 71.4 in August, marking the lowest outlook level in 10.5 years. This index is a "reliable short-run guide for current business conditions over time," the report said.

"In September, New York City purchasing managers expressed milestone pessimism about the long term indicators, the six-month outlook and expected revenues," ISM-New York said.
